channel.title: Chat Server-Client framework [With netty 5]
channel.description:
I wrote a simple chat. The server-client framework uses object serialization for communication and it's build with netty 5.
When the client is launched, it will try to connect to the server. If it failed, it will keep trying to connect in the background. You can't try to login as long as the server is off line. [img]http://i.imgur.com/pq6Blrg.png[/img]
When the server goes off line while already logged in, it will take you back to the authentication screen.
Once logged in with a unique username, the server will send a welcome message. If the username was already taken it will notice you of it on the authentication screen.
Then you can start chatting, where your message will be send to the server, and the server will send it back to you and to the users online. [img]http://i.imgur.com/BtegaBZ.png[/img]
For people interested: [b]Download source code:[/b] http://www.mediafire.com/download/0vtty6gdzose1du/Chat_Server-Client-System.zip

item.title: Chat Server-Client framework [With netty 5]
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“RandQm, post:8, topic:546789”]Can anybody tell me if it would be better to just use default java networking client-sided?
As it’s just 1 connection with the server I’m guessing you could leave the extra project size of netty aside?

Also I noticed a bug, that when the server reject your connection due to e.g. wrong credentials that you wont be able to re-attempt a login again unless you restart the client. It’s not a networking problem do so if you’re using this for network learning purposes it’s still alright, it’s a design problem I’m guessing, will look it in when I’m on my own computer.[/quote]
It depends. If the client is a big file in general (100mb+), I’m sure 9mb won’t really make a difference otherwise using something more lightweight would be best.
